l1.label: Positive Control
l1.feedback: The positive control graph shows four different cell lines. The correct choice is the unedited wild type macrophage cell lines (which was our starting material), where the gene of interest is at wild type levels of expression and has not been disrupted.
l1.text:
A positive control is a sample in an experiment that produces a known result to compare with the test sample after the same treatment. It is used to control for unknown variables and confirms that all your reagents work.

In this case, the positive control is a cell line expressing wild-type CCR5.

Which of the following do you think will be a good positive control for this experiment? Click on a cell line to select it.

choices.label: T Helper cell line
choices.feedback: A T cell is different from a macrophage and wouldn’t represent the best comparative control. Please try again.

choices.label: Macrophage cell line without CD4
choices.feedback: This cell line is not a functional immune cell. Please try again.

choices.label: Edited macrophage
choices.feedback: An edited macrophage cell line contains a changed CCR5 gene and would presumably not express wild-type CCR5 on its surface. Please try again.

choices.label: Unedited wild-type macrophage
choices.feedback: Correct. Wild-type macrophages carry the undisrupted CCR5 gene and express the co-receptor on the cell surface at normal levels. This serves as a standard to determine the CCR5 protein level in CRISPR-edited macrophages.

l2.label: Positive Control
l2.feedback: The positive control graph shows four different cell lines. The correct choice is the unedited wild type macrophage cell lines (which was our starting material), where the gene of interest is at wild type levels of expression and has not been disrupted.

Which of the following do you think will be a good positive control for this experiment? Click on a cell line to select it.

l3.text:

In this case, the positive control is a cell line expressing wild-type CCR5.

Which of the following do you think will be a good positive control for this experiment? Click on a cell line to select it.

choices.label: T Helper cell line
choices.feedback: A T cell is different from a macrophage and wouldn’t represent the best comparative control. Please try again.

choices.label: Macrophage cell line without CD4
choices.feedback: This cell line is not a functional immune cell. Please try again.

choices.label: Edited macrophage
choices.feedback: An edited macrophage cell line contains a changed CCR5 gene and would presumably not express wild-type CCR5 on its surface. Please try again.

choices.label: Unedited wild-type macrophage
choices.feedback: Correct. Wild-type macrophages carry the undisrupted CCR5 gene and express the co-receptor on the cell surface at normal levels. This serves as a standard to determine the CCR5 protein level in CRISPR-edited macrophages.

l1.label: Negative Control
l1.feedback: The negative control graph shows expression levels of the protein of interest in various cell types. Users need to click on one cell type to select an appropriate negative control. This correct answer is Pancreas.
l1.text:
The negative control is the opposite of the positive control: the positive control produces a known result, whereas the negative control is designed to produce no response after the same treatment.

In our example, a negative control would be a cell line not expressing CCR5. Accordingly, the protein gel should not show a CCR5 band. The negative control confirms that no contaminating or artefact band mimics CCR5 presence, even though there is no actual CCR5 protein present in the cells.

Which of the following cell lines will provide an effective negative control for this experiment? Expression levels of the protein of interest are shown next to each cell type as bars: the longer the bar, the higher the expression level of CCR5.

l2.label: Negative Control
l2.feedback: The negative control graph shows expression levels of the protein of interest in various cell types. Users need to click on one cell type to select an appropriate negative control. This correct answer is Pancreas.
l2.text:

Which of the following cell lines will provide an effective negative control for this experiment? Expression levels of the protein of interest are shown next to each cell type as bars: the longer the bar, the higher the expression level of CCR5.

l1.label: Next step
l1.text: After disrupting the CCR5 gene in the two macrophages cell lines 4 and 7 (now called edit 4 and edit 7), what will be your next experimental step to verify that these cell lines are now HIV-resistant macrophages?

choices.label: To test how well HIV infection of macrophages is inhibited.
choices.feedback: Incorrect. You are not ready to jump ahead to test whether your macrophage cell lines are HIV-resistant yet.

choices.label: To test for the presence of HIV RNA in your macrophage cell lines.
choices.feedback: Incorrect. Macrophages are not yet infected with HIV.

choices.label: To design a second set of gRNAs to disrupt gp120.
choices.feedback: Incorrect. Macrophages do not carry the gene encoding gp120 since it’s an HIV protein.

choices.label: To test the protein expression of CCR5.
choices.feedback: Correct.

props.label: What is the purpose of adding SDS to the cell cultures?

choices.label: SDS solubilizes membrane proteins.
choices.feedback: Partially correct. There are additional effects.

choices.label: SDS breaks down cell membranes and releases the cell content.
choices.feedback: Partially correct. There are additional effects.

choices.label: SDS destroys protein.
choices.feedback: Incorrect. SDS unfolds protein but does not destroy or alter the amino acid sequence.

choices.label: SDS unfolds proteins and covers them with negative charge. Negatively charged proteins can be separated in a protein gel according to mass after applying an electrical current.
choices.feedback: Partially correct. There are additional effects.

choices.label: All except C.
choices.feedback: Correct. All except C.

choices.label: All of the above.
choices.feedback: Incorrect. SDS unfolds protein but does not destroy or alter the amino acid sequence.

props.label: How should you micropipette samples into the wells?

choices.label: Quickly, so the proteins go down in the well.
choices.feedback: Incorrect.

choices.label: Slowly, to prevent it spilling over into the next well.
choices.feedback: Correct.

choices.label: Slowly, but move the plunger up and down to mix.
choices.feedback: Incorrect.

l1.task: Unplug the electrodes from the power supply.

l2.task: Unplug the electrodes from the power supply.

l3.task: Unplug the electrodes.

steps.aria: Unplug the electrodes from the power supply.

l1.task: Carefully remove the cover from the electrophoresis box to inspect your gel.

l2.task: Remove the cover to inspect your gel.

l3.task: Inspect your gel.

steps.aria: Carefully remove the cover from the electrophoresis box to inspect your gel

l1.label: Protein samples are separated using the following technique:

l2.label: SDS-PAGE is a technique for separating ______ based on their molecular weight.

l3.label: The reason we use Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate (SDS) in this assay is ________________.

choices.label: It creates the electric current that moves proteins through the gel.
SDS breaks down cell membranes and coats the entire unfolded protein in a shell of negative charge.
It allows us to visualise the proteins moving through the gel so that the gel can be stopped when the proteins reach the bottom of the gel.

l1.label: Using SDS imparts an overall _______ charge to the proteins.

l2.label: Why is the 4X SDS sample buffer added to the samples?

choices.label: To denature the proteins and coat the proteins with negative charges.
To prevent the samples from degrading.
To dilute the protein samples to the correct concentration.

l3.label: Why are samples heated before loading them on the SDS gel?

choices.label: Heating the samples will reduce clumping of proteins but will not alter the native 3-dimensional protein structure.
Heating the samples will destroy any possible contamination acquired from processing the samples in previous steps. This will ensure protein specificity during the Western blot process.

Heating the samples speeds up the protein denaturation process. This is important as proteins need to be unfolded in order to successfully separate out according to size during the SDS polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis step.

l1.label: In a PAGE gel, proteins are separated only based on their _______?

l2.label: Which of the following statements are true about SDS-PAGE?

choices.label: It separates proteins only by charge.
The main ingredient in the gel is agarose.
It requires a protein denaturing gel.

l3.label: Why might you rather want to run the SDS gel electrophoresis at a low voltage than a high voltage?

choices.label: A high voltage would cause all the proteins to travel at the same speed and will not separate them through the gel.
A high voltage would speed up the process and you are more likely to lose samples running off the gel.
A low voltage will generate less heat and provide better protein separation and band resolution.

l1.label: You receive the following gel after electrophoresis. What went wrong?
l1.ariaLabel: Image of a gel, showing the dye front halfway down the gel, with no results showing for the samples.

choices.label: You did not allow for enough time when running the gel.
The temperature of the gel during the run was too low.
You forgot to turn on the power source.

l2.label: Why is Sodium Dodecyl Sulfate (SDS) used in this assay?

choices.label: It creates the electric current that moves proteins through the gel.
SDS coats the entire protein in a shell of negative charge, allowing proteins to migrate toward the positive electrode.
It allows us to visualise the proteins moving through the gel so that the gel can be stopped when the proteins are separated.

l3.label: SDS sample buffer contains glycerol, which has a higher density than running buffer. Why is glycerol included in SDS sample buffer?

choices.label: The higher density of glycerol creates a denser sample buffer, ensuring that the protein samples sink to the bottom of the gel well.
Glycerol aids in the protein denaturation step as it acts as a detergent.
Glycerol ensures stability of the protein structure and helps with accurate protein separation.

l1.label: After running your protein gel, you can inspect the gel for protein bands and determine if your previous gene editing step worked. Is this statement true?

choices.label: Yes, running a protein gel is the final step of the experiment.
No, you need to visualize the protein bands first, preferably by Western blot.
No, the only way to determine if the experiment worked is to infect the edited cell lines with HIV.

l2.label: How can you confirm if the electric current is on and correctly applied to the gel system?

choices.label: You can see bubbles moving in the tank buffer and the blue sample buffer is traveling downwards.
You will not be able to detect this until the end.
You will see the blue sample buffer moving upwards from the wells.

l3.label: In this experiment, you aimed to detect the presence or absence of a specific protein produced by the CCR5 gene. What proteins were separated by size during the SDS PAGE gel electrophoresis?

choices.label: Only the CCR5 protein in the positive control and the protein ladder.
All cellular proteins in the ladder and the pancreas and macrophage cell lines.
All the different proteins encoded by the CCR5 gene.

l1.label: How confident do you feel about using the technique you learned?

l2.label: How confident do you feel about using the technique you learned?

l3.label: How confident do you feel about using the technique you learned?
